description_x: Durable is an online platform that assists service businesses with the setup, templates, marketing, and invoicing of their company.
description_y: Durable is an online platform that assists service businesses with the setup, templates, marketing, and invoicing of their company.
headquarters_regions: San Francisco Bay Area, West Coast, Western US
review_text:
I have so many questions and concerns about this "website builder." However, before delving into them, I must caution against relying on this tool for any important purposes, especially if you are considering using it for business. The reason being that you will not have ownership of your website, as you are unable to copy or export the code. The CRM is a nice feature; however, my suggestion is that if you have to choose, it would be better to invest in your website, spend the money on branding, and design so that customers will remember and admire you and using an Excel spreadsheet to keep track of your client information. This way, in the event that this company goes out of business, you will not lose your website as you will have ownership of the code.

The strangest aspect of this business model is the many roles that the owner is attempting to play. Durable is asking users to either buy insurance from them or disclose information about their current insurance policies. However, Durable has not provided any explanation as to why they need access to users' financial information, nor is there any evidence to support their legal authority to conduct insurance business. Additionally, Durable would like to be your money manager, but it is unclear why Durable is qualified to act as a money manager for your business, as they have not provided any credentials or meaningful information on their expertise in this area. It seems that Durable wants to have control over every aspect of your life, business, and finances, manage your money, and in return, you will have no ownership. The creator's approach to launching a business website is unusual, and I strongly advise against sharing any personal information or giving them money. Please review their terms of service, which specifically state that they will own your website and that they can change the terms of service at any time. Check Crunchbase to see that this company was formed in 2021 and is in the early stages of financing with an investment firm. Please do not be deceived into thinking that you will have any legal recourse if this is not what it appears to be or if the owners decide to pivot their business strategy and leave you with nothing.

Edit: I have one more thing to say. It is troubling that Durable focuses on attracting very tiny, startup companies. It's important to keep in mind that they will never truly own the site, despite the fact that some business owners, such as dog walkers, artists, and daycare center owners, may see it as a way to avoid the perceived hassle of establishing a website. They will always be reliant on Durable, and they will have to continue making payments to keep the site up and running or risk losing it altogether. If you're a small business owner seeking a risk-free option to quickly and easily build a website, Google Business is worth considering, but you *must* learn how to customize your website for SEO or search engines will never find you. Google Business is a free platform with drag-and-drop customization options. Additionally, if you ever decide to switch platforms, you can use the takeout feature to download your website and take it with you. You might need up to a week to build it, but isn't it worth it? Although it doesn't seem as magical as this product, you won't run the chance of losing your website. To begin, create a company profile and follow the guided setup process. You can use the available tools and templates to build a website that reflects your brand's identity and even add code for further customization, if desired. Although you may want to think about hiring an expert in the future, Google Business is a great way to build your online presence quickly and for no cost. Try it out. You've got this!

review_text:
Brilliant product, excited to see where it goes. Fun to use if you enjoy trying to create engaging and human conversational flows. *nerd alert*

Two things I don't love: 1. Needs work for our mobile visitors. Looks zoomed out and far from optimal for a mobile visitor, a bad experience on this is worse than no experience at all, so a bit of a showstopper for me at the moment, for risk of providing a bad experience (no way of tracking or following this experience to check it's going smooth for mobile visitors, so a tiny risk to go live with if have lots of visitors on mobile)

Secondly, at the end of every flow on the freemium a "share this Landbot" button appears alongside a CTA to create their own. Obviously, I get it, it's a free product, do what you want. If I want to remove that, I can pay to do so. Just my personal opinion, and more feedback than a request, is that I think it's a bad time to "Hijack" MY visitors attention to market YOUR product at what is often for these forms, the critical moment, the end. They're at a decision crossroads. We've just exchanged information, i've taken them on this journey, and then BAM, you come and sweep them off their feet and they forget all the sweet nothings they and i whispered to each other.

My only point is, IF others have this gripe too, they might leave and not give the product a chance to become part of their paid stack, instead of upgrading straight away to remove this barrier to them. If this barrier didn't exist, (your branding is still on the page top right anyway), they may implement, become an active user, and give you plenty of time to convert them to a paid plan as you continue to execute and improve the product from now on out.

Keep up the great work.

description_y: Branded Marketing Content Creation - Automated Through AI
review_text:
I can see myself using this for side projects. Onboarding is clear and fast and task completion is a breeze as well. UI is friendly, except for the FRAMES section on the left, when I create a post: personally I wasn't able to understand what their function is because their imagery seemed unrelated with my post and when I clicked on few of them they seemed to get selected but nothing happened. They must have a function, and I always have a super dummy approach when I try and review new apps so maybe you could try to improve the informational side of what does what. Just my 2 cents, of course.

Personally, I would also add a publish button to post making window/draft, maybe beside PREVIEW. Right now it seems to be only available from the 3 dots on the CONTENT page. It makes perfect sense, don't misunderstand me, but whenever one step can be saved I'd always go for that.

All the above don't affect my rating because it is expected to have terrain for improvement at launch, especially when it comes to UI and documentation.

The issue I have is with AI-powered imagery: that technology is still far away from being usable in apps like this, because the results are awful. Those of Stori AI are not even that bad, but still not viable for branding, in my opinion. Thing is that this is a common problem to all similar apps right now, so I don't feel like it is a flaw of this particular app. My suggestion to anybody offering this kind of tech in an automated way as a feature of their app is to always "sell it" as a beta feature while offering in-app editing tools for real imagery as the selling point, because AI-powered imagery doesn't meet customers' expectations yet.

About AI-powered text, to the contrary, there's really good prompting behind this app, and with a bit of manual editing here and there one can really save time and money. That makes it a worthy app with great potential, to me; one that I will use for some of my side projects, and whose evolution I'll certainly keep an eye on. 👀

Definitely supporting it.
